Author: timr
Content:
Read the article.

What caused the earth to get warmer?

"the National Academy of Sciences report, Climate Change Science: An Analysis of Some Key Questions, begins: "Greenhouse gases are accumulating in Earth's atmosphere as a result of human activities, causing surface air temperatures and subsurface ocean temperatures to rise" [p. 1 in (5)]. The report explicitly asks whether the IPCC assessment is a fair summary of professional scientific thinking, and answers yes: "The IPCC's conclusion that most of the observed warming of the last 50 years is likely to have been due to the increase in greenhouse gas concentrations accurately reflects the current thinking of the scientific community on this issue" [p. 3 in (5)]."

Will it continue?

Directly from the IPCC report:

http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/035.htm#temperature

"Global mean temperature continues to increase for hundreds of years at a rate of a few tenths of a degree per century after concentrations of CO2 have been stabilised, due to long time-scales in the ocean....If greenhouse gas concentrations were stabilised (even at present levels), sea level would nonetheless continue to rise for hundreds of years....The loss of a substantial fraction of the total glacier mass is likely. Areas that are currently marginally glaciated are most likely to become ice-free."

Author: sethjohn
Content:
There are really a couple of separate issues here. First, it is important to distinguish between the general scientific agreement about past climate changes and the greater confusion about the probability of future climate changes. One of the main reasons why there is such broad agreement among the community is that scientists have tended to focus on the answerable questions such as "has the earth been getting warmer over the last X years" rather than the thornier question of "what caused the earth to get warmer" and "will the earth continue to get warmer." Very few scientific papers have been written that make predictions on the question of future climate.

It is also important to remember that while there is generally scientific consensus that global warming is "probably" happening (whatever that means!) or that it is "probably" caused by humans, there is a great deal of uncertaintly about exactly what the probabilities are. If you could get all scientists to agree that there was about a 71% chance that the next century would be warmer, does that count as "scientific consensus that climate change is likely"?

Author: kyro
Content:
I know this is cliche, but it wouldn't hurt to add social networking capabilities. This is actually an idea of mine I applied to YC with two cycles ago. It was a social network for product reviews and product prices where users would gather in interest groups (gaming pc's, music rigs) and bookmark the products they have, or want, on their profiles. Users would then jump from user to user to see what set up others are using. Each product would have it's own page with a rating, reviews, and scour the internet for the best prices. Not only would you index new products by scouring the net, but users would be motivated to find new products and submit them to your site.

More realistically, however, I think a feature that allows users to bookmark products and receive alerts when new lower prices have been found would increase stickiness. Imagine a user coming to your site, bookmarking a product and sort of forgetting about it, only to find an email alert telling them a lower price has been found, and they're back.

Author: timr
Content:
The only "pet cause" that I have, is to debunk the notion that outsider opinions in science should be given consideration because they are in the minority.

I'm sorry if you were confused by my use of rhetoric. However, it gave you a chance to lecture me on the properties of science ("models and experiments"), so perhaps it wasn't time wasted?

Author: timr
Content:
http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/306/5702/1686

"That hypothesis was tested by analyzing 928 abstracts, published in refereed scientific journals between 1993 and 2003, and listed in the ISI database with the keywords "climate change" (9).

The 928 papers were divided into six categories: explicit endorsement of the consensus position, evaluation of impacts, mitigation proposals, methods, paleoclimate analysis, and rejection of the consensus position. Of all the papers, 75% fell into the first three categories, either explicitly or implicitly accepting the consensus view; 25% dealt with methods or paleoclimate, taking no position on current anthropogenic climate change. Remarkably, none of the papers disagreed with the consensus position.

Admittedly, authors evaluating impacts, developing methods, or studying paleoclimatic change might believe that current climate change is natural. However, none of these papers argued that point.

This analysis shows that scientists publishing in the peer-reviewed literature agree with IPCC, the National Academy of Sciences, and the public statements of their professional societies. Politicians, economists, journalists, and others may have the impression of confusion, disagreement, or discord among climate scientists, but that impression is incorrect."

Author: emfle
Title: Scott Adams: Giving Stuff Away on the Internet
Content: "So I've been watching with great interest as the band "Radiohead" pursues its experiment with pay-what-you-want downloads on the Internet. In the near term, the goodwill has inspired lots of people to pay. But I suspect many of them are placing a bet that paying a few bucks now will inspire all of their favorite bands to offer similar deals. That's when the market value of music will approach zero."

Author: DanielBMarkham
Content:
You said you were confused about the point of the article. I believe I have explained the purpose of op-eds.

Now I believe you are trying get into a discussion about global warming. My suggestion is that if you are still confused, the topic of your confusion should be "why op-eds about my pet causes bother my sensibilities"

I'm afraid I do not have an answer to that question. I'm not trying to be a flip with you, it just seems your initial post was not as clear as it could have been. I'm sure there are lots of folks who would like to argue global warming with you. I am not one of them.

Author: sethjohn
Content:
It is not true that there is overwhelming scientific consensus about the probability of climate change. While I would agree that most scientists think that it is most likely that "global warming is real", there is a great deal of uncertainty among even the worlds leading climate scientists about the probability of global warming.

A few years ago I ran a betting game among students and faculty in the MIT climate program, the idea was to develop some feeling for the 'community consensus' of the likelyhood of global warming. The conclusion: ~71% chance of global warming over the next century.

http://www.sethjohn.com/PAOC%20CFM/slide1.html

Author: timr
Content:
Thousands of peer-reviewed studies (that means models and experiments) have come to the conclusion that global warming is real, and is caused by human activity.

It may be "interesting" that one guy in Alabama disagrees with the overwhelming scientific consensus on this issue, but it's certainly no more interesting than the members of the flat earth society, or my great uncle Fred, who happens to think that radio waves cause cancer.

Author: DanielBMarkham
Content:
Repeat after me: model and reproducible experiment, model and reproducible experiment. All science is provisional and must maintain falsifiability for it to be called science.

Statements about how many scientists believe any thing, from phrenology to aether to gravity, is an interesting observation about the current opinions and politics of those who practice science. It is not science itself.

Author: run4yourlives
Content: Agreed, that's an entirely useless article with little information save his opinion.

Author: timr
Content:
Indeed. 99.99% of the world's scientists, based on careful interpretation of many thousands of peer-reviewed studies, agree that global warming is real, and is caused by human activity.

A vanishingly small handful of scientists happen to disagree with this assessment, based mostly upon their opinion and politics.
